title: Uber and Lyft decline to appear before U.S. Congress
text:
The House Transportation and Infrastructure Committee had asked the ride-hailing companies to answer questions about safety, road congestion and driver wages. Peter DeFazio, who chairs the federal transportation committee, said Wednesday the panel plans to pursue legislation with or without the companies’ cooperation. (Reuters)

Talking point: The inquiry is part of lawmakers’ process to regulate the ride-hailing industry amid pushback against the companies’ treatment of workers, as well as its impact on congestion and emissions. In September, employees in Uber’s special investigation unit said they were under pressure to put the company’s interest over passenger safety, and Lyft was recently accused of mishandling sexual harassment reports. The companies have so far resisted regulations. For example, Uber maintains that a California law passed in September that would require app-based companies to give their core workers employee status doesn’t apply to it.
